article:
The 'inventive step' and 'non-obviousness' reflect a same general patentability
requirement present in most patent laws, according to which an invention should
be sufficiently inventive — i.e., non-obvious — in order to be
patented. In other words, "[the] nonobviousness
principle asks whether the invention is an adequate distance beyond or above the
state of the art." Barton, John H. (2003)

The expression "inventive step" is predominantly used in Europe, while the
expression "non-obviousness" is predominantly used in United States patent
law. Although the basic principle is roughly the same, the
assessment of the inventive step and non-obviousness varies from one country to
another. For instance, the practice of the European Patent Office (EPO) differs
from the practice in the United Kingdom.
